channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Pilgrim in Violent Land, Suspect Found Comfort in Dagestan
item.description: Tamerlan Tsarnaev, one of the suspects in the Boston bombings, found comfort in Dagestan, a region in the North Caucasus that is the center of violent Islamic insurgency in Russia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patimat Suleimanova, with her husband, Mukhammad, described a reunion with their nephew Tamerlan Tsarnaev as happy.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Report Says Myanmar Was Complicit in Anti-Muslim Violence
item.description: A report by a human rights group accuses Myanmar’s government of standing by, or worse, as Buddhists conducted a campaign of violence against Muslims.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Ye Aung Thu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered at the Shwedagon Pagoda in Yangon in June after unrest flared in the state of Rakhine, also known as Arakan, in western Myanmar.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In China, the Shared Grief of Losing a Single Child Like Lu Lingzi
item.description: With their daughter’s death in the Boston Marathon attack, the parents of Lu Lingzi joined a growing group in China — parents who lose a single child in a country that mandates one child for many.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A woman holding a baby on a Beijing street. The Chinese government's strict controls on family size, including a one-child policy for some, especially urban families, has limited population growth but also created a sizable group of parents who have lost their only children.

item.title: Political Economy: The Gloom Around Greece Is Dissipating
item.description: Although the economy will have a terrible 2013, next year should be better. But the outlook is fragile: political crisis could yet again occur.
item.dc:creator: By HUGO DIXON | REUTERS

item.title: Hollywood’s Box Office Heroes Proving Mortal in China
item.description: Hollywood blockbusters appeared poised last year to take over China’s box office, but something unexpected happened on the way to the bank: demand tapered off sharply.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: Performers in Iron Man garb at the Tai Miao temple in Beijing this month. “Iron Man 3” has been heavily promoted in China.

item.title: Chinese Auto Market Shifts Toward Larger Cars
item.description: Auto buyers in what is the world’s largest car market are shifting away from compacts and subcompacts and buying more midsize cars and sport utility vehicles.
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER
item.media:description: Sport utility vehicles at the Shanghai auto show. S.U.V.’s have achieved new popularity in China.

item.title: Opposition Leader Rallies Italians in Protest After President Is Re-elected
item.description: Beppe Grillo of the Five Star Movement organized supporters to express dismay at the tactics behind the election that assured a second term for President Giorgio Napolitano.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Beppe Grillo, center, the founder of the antiestablishment Five Star Movement, during a news conference in Rome on Sunday.

item.title: Horacio Cartes Wins Paraguay’s Presidential Election
item.description: Electoral officials declared Horacio Cartes of the Colorado Party the winner after voters seemed ready to give Mr. Cartes the benefit of the doubt over claims of drug-trafficking and other charges leveled against him.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man in Asunción, Paraguay, cast his vote in Sunday’s election. Electoral authorities declared Horacio Cartes the winner.

item.title: Police Under New Scrutiny After Activist Dies in Egypt
item.description: The death has underscored one of the most vexing challenges facing the new government: how to tame Egypt’s unaccountable and despised security forces.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Egyptians at the funeral in February of Mohamed el-Gindy. The activist was found dead after he protested in Tahrir Square.

item.title: Syrian Troops Move on Town Near Damascus
item.description: Syrian opposition activists said Sunday that government forces had killed at least 80 people in Jdaidet al-Fadl and then made mass arrests as residents tried to bury the bodies.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and HALA DROUBI
item.media:description: President Bashar al-Assad meeting a Lebanese delegation on Sunday in a photo provided by SANA, the state news agency.

item.title: Civilians Are Killed in Nigerian Battle
item.description: Fighting between the country’s military and Islamic extremists killed at least 185 people in a fishing community in the northeast, officials said Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Europe Heeding International Call to Do More to Spur Growth
item.description: As unemployment continues to rise, some officials on the Continent have said a renewed focus on growth might be appropriate.
item.dc:creator: By ANNIE LOWREY
item.media:description: Wolfgang Schäuble of Germany with Christine Lagarde.

item.title: Rape of Girl, 5, Draws Focus to Child Assault in India
item.description: Amid angry protests, another girl who was raped was treated in the same hospital as the 5-year-old who was tortured last week.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Police confronted women in New Delhi on Sunday who were protesting the rape of a 5-year-old girl.

item.title: London Marathon Is Completed Without Security Problems
item.description: Six days after the Boston bombings, the London Marathon was held Sunday with no security scares and the minds of nearly all on the victims of last week’s attack.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
item.media:description: Runners observed a moment of silence in tribute to the victims of the Boston Marathon bombings before the start of the London Marathon on Sunday.

item.title: Japanese Cabinet Ministers Visit Contentious War Shrine
item.description: Japan’s prime minister, Shinzo Abe, sent an offering to the shrine for Japan’s war dead but did not visit with his cabinet ministers, possibly to avoid provoking China and South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Anna Merz, Protector of Black Rhinos, Dies at 81
item.description: Mrs. Merz founded a wildlife reserve in Kenya that has helped the black rhinoceros come back from the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Anna Merz with a rhinoceros named Samia.

item.title: Reporter for Government Radio Is Killed in Somalia
item.description: Mohamed Ibrahim Rageh had fled Mogadishu, the Somali capital, in 2009 after a spate of killings, but returned to continue his career.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Chechens in U.S. Fear Reprisals
item.description: After the suspects in the Boston bombings were identified as being of Chechen origin, Chechens in the United States said the attack had left them feeling exposed and embarrassed.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Teaching the Limits of Media Freedom Is Tricky in the Gulf
item.description: The principles of modern journalistic freedom often clash with governments that can deport or detain reporters.
item.dc:creator: By D.D. GUTTENPLAN

item.title: Indians Hope to Raise Journalism Standards
item.description: New schools face an uphill struggle in training professionals for an industry that is often less than perfectly ethical.
item.dc:creator: By GAYATRI RANGACHARI SHAH

item.title: China Expands Crackdown on Anticorruption Activists
item.description: Six more activists were detained after demanding that Communist Party officials disclose their personal wealth, another sign of the limits of the leadership’s war on graft.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Pakistani Taliban Violently Reshape the Ballot
item.description: An intense campaign of attacks in the region has all but derailed the governing party and has struck fear in its candidates.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers stood by recently as Shahid Khan, a provincial assembly candidate, spoke in Nowshera, Pakistan. His party has been targeted by the Taliban.

item.title: Kerry Urges Erdogan to Postpone Gaza Trip
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry expressed concern that a visit by Turkey’s leader could harm efforts to restart the Israeli-Palestinian peace process.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry answered questions after meetings in Istanbul on Sunday which focused on renewing peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 20
item.description: Arrest in Boston bombing; new risky investments; drug maker under scrutiny, and moves against tax evasion.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: After Boston and Tsarnaevs, Russians Urge U.S. to Rethink Chechnya
item.description: Despite strained relations with Washington, the Kremlin has offered its help in the Boston bombing investigation. Russian commentators suggest a Chechen connection to the attack may force the U.S. to reconsider how it sees Moscow’s own war on terror.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Tamerlan Tsarnaev, 26, left, and Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, 19.
